Award.AwardTitle: Arabidopsis 2010: Simultaneous Genome Wide Association Mapping in Plant Host and Pathogen
Award.AbstractNarration: Infectious disease has long been studied either via investigations into the pathogen or host. However, it is more appropriate to consider disease as the outcome of how the genomes from two organisms interact, especially for endemic diseases which cause significant and persistent losses in numerous economic arenas ranging from agriculture to business. This project will begin one of the first investigations into how the genetic diversity present in entire host and pathogen genomes simultaneously interact to control the infection outcome. Using next generation sequencing with a diverse and destructive plant pathogen, Botrytis cinerea (grey mold), and a model plant, Arabidopsis thaliana, this project will specifically identify diversity networks that enable an endemic plant disease to overcome diverse and fluctuating plant defenses. This will provide unique insight into how endemic diseases may evolve and provide ideas of how to counter this evolution. Additionally, this project will provide novel insights and guidance into how to conduct genome wide association studies on complex phenotypes such as disease. The project will involve a highly integrative combination of biology, genetics, biochemistry and computational genomics all within a single laboratory that will provide an optimal platform in which to train future scientists that can take full advantage of all genomic technologies to more efficiently solve societies pressing questions and problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pathogens can be classified as epidemic (Influenza, Potato blight, etc) or endemic (common cold, Botrytis cinerea, etc) depending on their behaviour within the infected host. While the biology of epidemic pathogens and how they attack their hosts are well understood, much less is known about how endemic pathogens may affect their hosts. In this study, we used a model system involving the common lab plant Arabidopsis thaliana (mouse ear cress) and the endemic plant pathogen Botrytis cinerea (grey mold; common on household fruits). Using this model system, we investigated the genomic variation in the host and pathogen that control how the host and pathogen attack each other. This work showed that whereas epidemic diseases are frequently the result of a few large effect genes interacting, our endemic system was a result of hundreds of genes in both the plant host and the fungal pathogen that somehow interact to control the disease outcome. This situation is called a polygenic system and is at the heart of a large number of traits in both plants and humans but with little mechanistic insight as to how they work.

Using this polygenic model of endemic disease, we worked to identify the mechanisms underpinning the disease response. By measuring the RNA response of the plant host to a population of 96 genotypes of the fungal pathogen, we were able to show that the disease outcome could be predicted by measuring only 200 transcripts in the host soon after infection with the pathogen. These 200 genes were the major defense mechanism in the plant but interestingly, it was the early response prior to activation of the defense that predicted resistance. This suggests that with new technologies, that it might be possible to measure how a polygenic system is behaving by measuring a subset of the system. For example, in our polygenic model of endemic disease, there were 25,000 genes that responded to infection but we only needed to measure less than 1 percent of these to know what was going to occur. Being able to predict polygenic systems behaviour is a key to a number of health related traits in humans and agricultural traits like yield in plants and animals.

     In addition to addressing the biological complexities of endemic diseases, this project also supported the training of new experts in the quantitative analysis of big data with a focus on understanding new biology. The use of massive datasets to understand biology is likely a key aspect of any future study and there is a driving need to train new researchers to be able to conduct the computational and mathematical aspects of this research but also who can understand the underlying biology. This project allowed the training of multiple graduate students, undergraduates and post-doctoral researchers into the methods need to accomplish all of this to properly utilize large data to understand biology.
